author: MarketOracle
body:
Here's the problem with their business model, and it states it up front in their prospectus that most investors aren't willing to read. Their customer acquisition costs are very expensive. They spend several hundred thousands trying to acquire a customer because it requires them sending developers to a client, writing custom code to ingest data, and then hope the client signs up with them. If the client does not, then they lose that developer time. The hope is that the client signs up and pays an initial subscription cost. Then over time, the client would request additional data to be ingested, which increases cost to the customer. Finally, they hope that their systems will be so integrated with the client's systems, that they cannot be easily replaced or it would not be cost-effective to do so. That's when they will profit the most from the client.

Here's the problem. They haven't been profitable in 17 years because this business model doesn't work. It is limited by the number of developers available to implement their platform into different client systems. This is the painstaking manual process.

Here is my opinion: it is a high-millions, low-billion dollar business, but nothing that will scale like Adobe, Netflix, and other cloud services. They may have the best product in the world, but just like any product, you need sales. 125 customers after 17 years is an average of 7 customers a year. Also, they need positive cash flow. Instead, they have increasing operating costs and uncertain profit because some of their clients have downscaled services or cancel completely. $10 IPO was cheap. I considered, but passed. Great that some were able to double their money so far. But right now, it is risky. MoviePass was a great product for their customers, but their increasing operating costs due to their bad business model was their downfall.

author: spike_owens
body:
I sat through a Palantir demo, and while it looks nice, it reminded me a lot of elastic search, so I just googled Palantir + Elastic Search, and they basically are (or were) just using open source elastic as the method of working with unstructured data. 

&#x200B;

> Elasticsearch at Palantir  
Elasticsearch plays a key part in Gotham, one of Palantir's core platforms that powers a wide range of applications in areas such as law enforcement, mortgage fraud detection, and disaster response. In this talk, we'll give an overview of how Elasticsearch is used at Palantir and demo one of the latest applications, a tool that helps lawyers investigate financial wrongdoing. We'll then discuss how we made the switch to Elasticsearch from a custom solution built on Lucene and Postgres. The focus will be on one of our biggest challenges, implementing performant, fine-grained access control. 

The main "proprietary" portion of PLTR as far as I could find, is that they've developed some custom APIs to streamline data processing, so if you're constantly getting real time data, they've put in work to make that process faster and more reliable. 

It kind of makes sense if that's truly what makes them special that they tried to get into finance, since that's one of the few industries dealing with billions of transactions a day where speed of classification is really important. The fact that they haven't made many inroads in that sector makes me question how much value they have outside of government agencies.

After looking at Palantir I decided to invest in Elastic instead, but I don't have a lot of conviction in that pick. I just viewed the fact that Elastic already has more customers than Palantir, especially among large corporations, as a roadblock for Palantir gaining share among corporations. Obviously Palantir isn't only Elastic Search, but that's really the core functionality that most companies want, and since Elastic is open source, all of the major developers either already have, or soon will develop a GUI that's the equivalent of the Palantir front end (such as Adobe Sensei).

author: Logaratyunas
body:
Amazon has been making a loss until the late 2000s. Many other company have not been making a profit. Take Snowflake which have a lower revenue and still negative profit being valued over twice of Palantir. 

The main reason why it was making a loss is because it has very high initial customer acquisition costs, similar to Microsoft and Adobe back in the 80s when they were developing for enterprise. Except Palantir engineers must learn on hand the data from various industries and specially tailor the software to fit the individual customers better. Their profits are becoming less negative over the years as they increase their customer base and retention rates, and as their credibility and reputation increases. 

Microsoft and Adobe were B2B before with their software before jumping 200000% since the 1980s. If Palantir could create, transfer and scale their data AI technologies to everyday consumers and become a big name in the future, they will easily be a multi trillion dollar company. If they don't, at least I know they won't go bankrupt with their military dependence hahaha.

author: Dronez
body:
I've been using Adobe products for over a decade. I'm a subscriber. I would not buy their stock at these prices.

There are some extremely powerful competitors - Affinity, Davinci Resolve, and they are available for a fraction of the price, no subscription needed. Adobe keeps pouring money into bullshit apps like Premiere Rush or Fresco that literally nobody who is a professional gives a shit about.

My suggestion would be to put it into something like Unity instead, and bet on it becoming the "Adobe" of video game making. The learning curve isn't that bad, and it's cheap/free for people to start making stuff. The next generation wants to make video games, not commercials.

Disclosure I have 40 shares of Unity.

author: bbenecke3636
body:
Their IP is their platform, same as uber and lyft and other companies which have utilized technology to build a platform that disrupts existing business models. Does uber not have any existing moat, or airbnb? There's arguably high barriers of entry, tons of brand name value, solid interfaces. Quality algorithms and connection tools. I didnt say a disruptor in itself is a tech company, a tech company is quite literally a company that sells technology or technology services, which is precisely what air bnb is. Its a technology service.

UA is not a tech company, thats not really being debated anywhere. They are retail, without producing clothing, the additional tech wouldn't matter. The company isn't selling tech or services, they're selling clothes with some tech built in. Airbnb sells technology services, no differently than Adobe does

author: Afrofreak1
body: With all do respect to the guy, I think Buffet has way past his prime. He made his money during a period in time where you could measure the value of a company by its tangible assets. That is no longer the case when you have firms that are able to write lines of code and then sell carbon copies of it billions of times over on a monthly subscription base à la Adobe for example. What other company has an 87% gross margin? Obviously if you apply traditional metrics to a company like that it's going to look overvalued, which is why he has underperformed the S&P500 by quite a margin since 2008.

author: TheyHaveTheVaccine
body:
I'm not sure if this is ok to post here, but I just wanted to lay out where my money is, and ask what anybody has to think of say, and if I am being an idiot, or am I so a decent path or not. 

I recently had a large windfall after my equity in a startup got bought out. More money than Id ever thought I'd have at one time - not retirement money, but set myself up for my future if I make the right moves money. I'm a 30 year old dude, no kids, no mortgage, not married, no crazy big expenses...make 60k a year now, hopefully a raise at the end of the year and my company is one of the incredibly lucky ones to be thriving right now. So, I figure I can definitely be a little risky. But I don't want to be an IDIOT. Any and all advice would be humble and sincerely appreciated (I didn't even have a savings account before this because I was an idiot)

Roughly 100k after taxes. 

I reinvested 35% back into my company, and they matched the investment as an incentive. Only a select few of us were able to do this. 

I have 10k in Tmobile money, as a tmobile customer. So getting 4% on 3k and 1% on everything after. (Higher than any high yield savings accounts right now it looks like!)

Spent some, of course. But, I also decided to try my hand at the market. Not sure if this is ok to post here? But wanted to show my portfolio as well as it's about 10k. Any thoughts are very welcomed! Any insults for being an idiot are also welcomed, if that is the case.

author: chuck_portis
body:
Little competition?  It's a document signing app valued @ $42 Billion USD.  A competent team of developers could whip up a brand new competitor that likely improves on DocuSign's software in a matter of 6 months.

They already have dozens of competitors as it is, including Adobe who has a flawless and easy to use e-signing system which integrates seamlessly into PDF's, which is a document type they basically invented.

author: chuck_portis
body:
DocuSign is one of several players in the space.  They have plenty of competition from Adobe Sign, HelloSign, etc.  The network effect you see from platforms like Facebook (high), or even Zoom (medium), just isn't there for Docusign.  Only the sender needs to be on-boarded.  The receiver and easily sign documents without an account on the e-sign platforms.

This software is extremely basic and easy to replicate.  DocuSign is worth $42B on this product alone, which even has many free alternatives from competitors.  You might get some meme push on a rotation into stay-at-home's, but the downside on this one far outweighs the upside, in my opinion.

author: Newtothisredditbiz
body:
AAPL had already gone up 2000% between its first iPod release in 2001 and when I bought it in 2009. 

MSFT went up 6000% from 1986 to 1996 thanks to the PC revolution it helped build. 

ADBE went up 2000% in the same time period, thanks to its revolutionary desktop publishing software.

Those are just a few off the top of my head.

-----------

I wasn't that lucky, nor particularly smart. I just invested in companies that were obviously changing how people live and work.

Many investors have gotten far richer than me investing that way, and not just in tech. Nike, SBUX, Wal-Mart, Home Depot, Coca-Cola, Lululemon and the Gap are just some of the companies that have changed the world, and grew exponentially for years. 

In 2006, nobody was sitting at a Starbucks in their yoga pants, texting with an iPhone. By 2016, everybody was. That didn't happen overnight, and it didn't happen without a shitload of investors seeing those companies grow, and putting their money in.

author: 10min_no_rush
body:
I really don’t know why people think lockup period means stock is gonna tank.

I’m a senior engineer in SV. I have friends with hundreds of thousands of equity in a single company. My friend at Adobe has been working there 6 years, and he’s yet to sell a single share unless it was used to spend money.

The people who have great amounts of stock options in these tech companies tend to be people who are good at their jobs and they tend to have higher salaries.

Not saying ZI might not go down, but basing it off of lock up expire is kinda silly

author: Logaratyunas
body:
The only big investor is Soros, who regrets buying Facebook and Google back in 2018 too.

It's financials is horrible mainly to trick the algorithm by posting super negative one-off revenue. Its revenue has been growing, and its profit has been less negative too.

The pump may be quite crazy right now but remember ebr, they are involved in the COVID tracing, and vaccine distribution, using their Tiberius platform.

Microsoft and Adobe were B2B with their software, Customizing for big customers and struggle to break even in the 1980s. Theyve since commercialise to the public consumers and look at where they are at now: Literally 200000% increase since the 1980s.

Palantir is on its way, from being CIA focused, to expanding to government  military, health and geography, to expanding to commercial business clients, if they make a jump to consumer and scale from there, it would easily be a multi trillion company. This is likely priced in already nonetheless...
